questions.text: What is a motif in literature?

choices: A recurring element that supports the theme
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A recurring element that supports the theme

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A foil character contrasts with another character to highlight their traits.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is an archetype?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: A universal symbol or pattern

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each archetype to its description.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes tragic flaw (hamartia)?

choices: A weakness that leads to downfall
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A weakness that leads to downfall

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Symbolism is when an object represents only itself.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Symbolism is when an object represents something beyond itself, like a deeper meaning or idea.

questions.text: Order the stages of the hero's journey.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a soliloquy?

choices: To reveal a character's inner thoughts to the audience
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To reveal a character's inner thoughts to the audience

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An unreliable narrator always tells the truth.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: An unreliable narrator may deceive, misunderstand, or have limited knowledge, making their account questionable.

questions.text: Match each literary movement to its characteristic.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of in medias res?

choices: It starts in the middle of the action
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It starts in the middle of the action

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Catharsis refers to emotional release experienced by the audience.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which literary device involves giving human qualities to non-human things?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Personification

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What distinguishes a dynamic character from a static character?

choices: Static characters are more important to the plot
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Dynamic characters undergo significant change

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Dramatic irony occurs when the audience knows something the characters do not.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the primary function of foreshadowing in a narrative?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: To hint at future events

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of conflict to its description.

rightItems: Struggle against cultural norms or institutions

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term describes when an author reveals a character through their actions, dialogue, and thoughts rather than direct description?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Indirect characterization

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the elements of Freytag's Pyramid from beginning to end.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A flashback interrupts the chronological sequence to show events from the past.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of using first-person point of view?

choices: It provides an objective view of all characters
It creates intimacy but limits perspective to one character
It allows the narrator to know everything
It removes bias from the narrative
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It creates intimacy but limits perspective to one character

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each narrative perspective to its characteristics.

rightItems: Uses 'I' and is limited to narrator's experience
Uses 'he/she' and focuses on one character's thoughts

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term refers to the atmosphere or emotional quality of a literary work?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Mood

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Tone refers to the author's attitude toward the subject or audience.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is an allegory?

choices: A story with a hidden moral or political meaning
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A story with a hidden moral or political meaning

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each poetic device to its example.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes verbal irony?

choices: When events turn out opposite to expectations
When a speaker says the opposite of what they mean
When the audience knows more than the characters
When a situation is described in excessive detail
questionOptions.correctAnswer: When a speaker says the opposite of what they mean

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Situational irony occurs when the outcome of a situation is the opposite of what was expected.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the term for a long narrative poem that celebrates heroic deeds?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Epic

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order these elements from most to least scope in literary analysis.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which element of a Shakespearean sonnet contains the resolution or turn?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The couplet

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of irony to its literary example.

rightItems: Saying 'What lovely weather' during a storm
The audience knows the killer's identity but the detective does not

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a bildungsroman?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: A coming-of-age novel

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A protagonist is always a morally good character.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A protagonist is the main character but not necessarily morally good; an antihero can be a protagonist.

questions.text: Which literary device involves an extended comparison between two unlike things using 'like' or 'as'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Extended simile

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the parts of a five-act play structure.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of an aside in drama?

choices: To address the audience directly while other characters do not hear
To signal the end of an act
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To address the audience directly while other characters do not hear

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each figure of speech to its definition.

rightItems: A statement that seems contradictory but reveals truth

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term describes a recurring image, symbol, or theme across different works of literature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Archetype

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An allusion is a direct reference to another literary work, historical event, or cultural element.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does the term 'deus ex machina' refer to?

choices: An unexpected intervention that resolves an impossible situation
questionOptions.correctAnswer: An unexpected intervention that resolves an impossible situation

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each genre to its defining characteristic.

rightItems: Ends in disaster for the protagonist
Ends happily, often with marriage or reconciliation

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes stream of consciousness as a narrative technique?

choices: Showing characters' unfiltered thoughts and feelings
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Showing characters' unfiltered thoughts and feelings

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order these events according to their typical placement in a tragedy.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A round character has multiple, complex personality traits.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the function of comic relief in a tragedy?

choices: To end the play on a happy note
To provide temporary relief from tension
To reveal the tragic hero's flaw
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To provide temporary relief from tension

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each Shakespearean play type to its characteristics.

rightItems: Often end with marriage and reconciliation
Dramatize English monarchs and political events
Center on a noble hero's downfall

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term describes words or phrases that appeal to the five senses?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Imagery

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The setting of a story includes only the physical location.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Setting includes time period, social context, and atmosphere as well as physical location.

questions.text: What is the effect of juxtaposition in literature?

choices: It creates a sense of mystery
It highlights contrasts by placing elements side by side
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It highlights contrasts by placing elements side by side

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The main character in a story is always called the protagonist.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a simile?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: A comparison using 'like' or 'as'

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A metaphor compares two things without using 'like' or 'as'.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the antagonist in a story?

choices: The character or force opposing the protagonist
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The character or force opposing the protagonist

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The climax is the most exciting or turning point of a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the theme of a literary work?

choices: The central message or insight about life
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The central message or insight about life

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each basic literary term to its definition.

rightItems: A person or figure in the story
Time and place of the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A stanza is a group of lines in a poem.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is dialogue in a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Conversation between characters

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Fiction tells stories that are made up or imagined.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the resolution of a story?

choices: The ending where conflicts are resolved
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The ending where conflicts are resolved

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'connotation' mean in literary analysis?

choices: The dictionary definition of a word
The emotional associations of a word
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The emotional associations of a word

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Denotation refers to the literal dictionary definition of a word.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a flat character?

choices: A character who changes throughout the story
A character with few personality traits
A character who tells the story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A character with few personality traits

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each term to its correct definition.

rightItems: The struggle or problem in a story
The perspective from which a story is told

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is exposition in a narrative?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Background information at the beginning

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Rising action builds tension toward the climax.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a rhyme scheme?

choices: The pattern of rhymes at the end of lines
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The pattern of rhymes at the end of lines

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the basic plot elements from first to last.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a prologue?

choices: To introduce background before the main story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To introduce background before the main story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An epilogue comes after the main story ends.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is internal conflict?

choices: A struggle within a character's mind
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A struggle within a character's mind

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each poetic term to its definition.

rightItems: Words that end with the same sound
The rhythmic pattern of a poem

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'syntax' refer to in literature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Sentence structure and arrangement

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of repetition in poetry?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: It creates emphasis and rhythm

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A monologue is a long speech by one character.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a subplot?

choices: To add depth and complexity to the main story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To add depth and complexity to the main story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of character to its description.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a frame story?

choices: A story told by multiple narrators
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A story within a story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Enjambment occurs when a sentence continues from one line to the next without punctuation.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the narrative elements by their typical appearance in a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is an extended metaphor?

choices: A metaphor developed over several lines or an entire work
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A metaphor developed over several lines or an entire work

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each narrative technique to its effect.

rightItems: Creates immediate engagement by starting mid-action
Provides background by showing past events

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a conceit in poetry?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: An elaborate and unusual comparison

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Blank verse is unrhymed poetry written in iambic pentameter.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the function of a chorus in Greek drama?

choices: To provide commentary and reflect on the action
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To provide commentary and reflect on the action

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the parts of a classical tragedy according to Aristotle.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What distinguishes a Petrarchan sonnet from a Shakespearean sonnet?

choices: The structure: octave/sestet vs. three quatrains/couplet
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The structure: octave/sestet vs. three quatrains/couplet

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each literary period to its key characteristic.

rightItems: Emphasis on morality and social reform
Revival of classical learning and humanism
Focus on reason and scientific thinking

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An apostrophe in poetry is when a speaker addresses an absent person or abstract concept.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the difference between tragedy and tragicomedy?

choices: Tragicomedy blends tragic and comic elements
Tragicomedy is only performed in theaters
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Tragicomedy blends tragic and comic elements

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each element of tragedy to its Greek term.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the significance of the Aristotelian unities in drama?

choices: They demand unity of time, place, and action for dramatic coherence
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They demand unity of time, place, and action for dramatic coherence

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the stages of mythological narrative structure.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Defamiliarization is a technique that makes familiar things seem strange to force readers to see them anew.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a volta in a sonnet?

choices: To mark a shift in thought or argument
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To mark a shift in thought or argument

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each complex literary device to its definition.

rightItems: Repetition at the end of successive clauses
Repetition at the beginning of successive clauses
Reversal of grammatical structures in successive clauses

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of using a non-linear narrative structure?

choices: It challenges readers to piece together the story and creates intrigue
It eliminates the need for a climax
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It challenges readers to piece together the story and creates intrigue

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The term 'palimpsest' in literary criticism refers to a text that shows traces of earlier erased writing, suggesting layers of meaning.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the significance of the unreliable narrator in modernist literature?

choices: It questions the nature of truth and subjective experience
It eliminates the need for plot
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It questions the nature of truth and subjective experience

questions.subject: Reading
